unnormalised: Builders in Chennai are facing material cost hikes. Cement prices have gone up by ₹50 per bag. That's a noticeable jump from ₹350 to ₹400/bag. Steel prices are also up by ₹2000 per ton.
normalised: Builders in Chennai are facing material cost hikes. Cement prices have gone up by rupee fifty per bag. That's a noticeable jump from rupee three hundred and fifty to rupee four hundred per bag. Steel prices are also up by rupee two thousand per ton.

unnormalised: This spike is causing delays. Many projects are getting extended. A 1200 sq ft house construction cost has already increased by Rs. 1.5 Lakhs. Contractors are quoting higher rates for new projects, saying they can't absorb the increases anymore.
normalised: This spike is causing delays. Many projects are getting extended. A one thousand two hundred square feet house construction cost has already increased by rupees one point five lakhs. Contractors are quoting higher rates for new projects, saying they can't absorb the increases anymore.

unnormalised: Labour costs are also playing a part, with daily wages for skilled workers rising to ₹800. The cost of transporting materials like sand and gravel has increased, too. The cost per cubic meter has increased by 10%, making things difficult.
normalised: Labour costs are also playing a part, with daily wages for skilled workers rising to rupee eight hundred. The cost of transporting materials like sand and gravel has increased, too. The cost per cubic meter has increased by ten percent, making things difficult.

unnormalised: Experts suggest using alternative materials to mitigate the cost. For example, fly ash bricks instead of the conventional ones. They claim this can save up to 15% on construction costs.
normalised: Experts suggest using alternative materials to mitigate the cost. For example, fly ash bricks instead of the conventional ones. They claim this can save up to fifteen percent on construction costs.
